title: 110_hr1297
content: The Act may be cited as the "Freedom's Way National Heritage Area Act". Congress finds that the cultural and natural legacies of an area encompassing 37 communities in Massachusetts and 8 communities in New Hampshire have made important contributions to the national character of America. Recognizing and protecting these legacies will help sustain the quality of life in the future. Significant legacies include the early settlement of the United States, the evolution of democratic forms of government, intellectual traditions of freedom and democracy, social ideas, religious freedom, and the contributions of immigrants and industry to ethnic diversity. The communities in the area value their cultural and natural legacies, needing a cooperative framework and technical assistance to achieve important goals. There is a Federal interest in supporting the development of a regional framework to conserve, protect, and bring recognition to the heritage of the area for future generations. Significant examples of the area's resources include Walden Pond State Reservation in Concord. The Freedom's Way Heritage Area Feasibility Study highlights nationally distinctive historical resources in Massachusetts and New Hampshire, including Walden Pond State Reservation, Minute Man National Historical Park, Shaker Villages, Wachusett Mountain State Reservation, Fitchburg Art Museum, Barrett House, Beaver Brook Farms, and Lost City of Monson. The Freedom's Way National Heritage Area is overseen by the Freedom's Way Heritage Association, Inc. The purposes of this Act are to foster relationships between the Secretary and various entities, preserve the area's historic identity, and manage its resources for future generations. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms related to the Freedom's Way National Heritage Area, including "Heritage Area," "Management entity," "Management plan," "Map," and "Secretary." The Freedom's Way National Heritage Area is established in Massachusetts and New Hampshire with defined boundaries that can be revised with approval. The Secretary will publish a legal description of the Heritage Area in the Federal Register. The Freedom's Way National Heritage Area is established in Massachusetts and New Hampshire with defined boundaries that can be revised with approval. The Map shall be on file and available for public inspection in the appropriate offices of the National Park Service. The Freedom's Way Heritage Association, Inc. will serve as the management entity for the Heritage Area. The management plan for the Freedom's Way National Heritage Area is established with defined boundaries that can be revised with approval. The Freedom's Way Heritage Association, Inc. will serve as the management entity for the Heritage Area. The management entity for the Freedom's Way National Heritage Area must develop and submit a management plan to the Secretary within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The plan should coordinate with various levels of government, involve stakeholders, recommend actions for resource protection, and identify funding sources. The management plan for the Freedom's Way National Heritage Area must include an inventory of resources, recommendations for resource management, and policies for protection. It should also involve intergovernmental cooperation and identify funding sources. The management plan for the Freedom's Way National Heritage Area includes agreements to manage and protect cultural, historic, and natural resources, support economic revitalization efforts, and a program of strategies and actions for implementation. This involves identifying roles of agencies and organizations, restoration and construction plans, and a program of public involvement. The management plan for the Freedom's Way National Heritage Area includes agreements to manage and protect cultural, historic, and natural resources, support economic revitalization efforts, and a program of strategies and actions for implementation. This involves identifying roles of agencies and organizations, restoration and construction plans, and a program of public involvement, annual work plans, annual reports, coordination of Federal, State, and local programs, interpretive and educational plan, proposed revisions to boundaries, and a process for resolving disputes informally. If the management entity fails to submit the management plan, the Heritage Area will lose Federal funding. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the plan within 90 days, considering public and governmental involvement, resource protection, and interpretation strategies. The management plan must adequately protect cultural and historic resources in the Heritage Area. If disapproved, the Secretary will provide reasons and recommendations for revisions within 60 days. The Secretary must approve or disapprove proposed revisions to the management plan within 60 days. Amendments that may substantially change the plan require approval before funds can be used for implementation. SEC. 6. AUTHORITIES, DUTIES, AND PROHIBITIONS OF THE MANAGEMENT ENTITY. The Management Entity under the Act has the authority to use funds for grants, agreements, hiring staff, obtaining funds, and contracting services. Their duties include prioritizing the implementation of actions in the management plan. The Management Entity has the authority to use funds for various purposes, including carrying out programs to protect resource values, promoting economic viability, establishing interpretive exhibits, developing recreational and educational opportunities, increasing public awareness, and restoring historic buildings in the Heritage Area. The Management Entity is responsible for installing signs, preparing and implementing a management plan, considering diverse interests, conducting public meetings, and submitting annual reports on accomplishments and finances. The management entity must provide records of expenses, income, and grants made, for audit by Congress, the Secretary, and government units. They are also required to ensure that all entities receiving federal funds make their expenditure records available for audit. Additionally, the management entity is prohibited from using federal funds to acquire real property. SEC. 7. TECHNICAL AND FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE; OTHER FEDERAL AGENCIES. Technical and financial assistance can be provided by the Secretary upon request of the management entity for the development and implementation of the management plan. Priority is given to actions that conserve cultural, historic, and natural resources of the Heritage Area, as well as provide educational and recreational opportunities. Federal funds can be used on non-federally owned property identified in the management plan. The Secretary can provide assistance for the development and implementation of the management plan, with priority given to conserving resources and providing educational opportunities. Federal entities conducting activities in the Heritage Area must consider the potential effects on the area, consult with the management entity, and strive to avoid adverse effects. The Secretary may also enter into cooperative agreements with organizations to carry out these efforts. SEC. 8. LAND USE REGULATION; APPLICABILITY OF FEDERAL LAW. The management entity in the Heritage Area provides assistance to protect resources and values, without affecting state or local land use regulations. It advocates for land management practices but does not infringe on private property rights. The management entity in the Heritage Area advocates for land management practices without infringing on private property rights or imposing additional burdens on property owners. Authorization of $10,000,000 for the Act with a $1,000,000 limit per fiscal year. Federal share of costs not to exceed 50%. Secretary's assistance authority terminates 15 years after enactment.
